message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The nasal polyp obstructing the superior nasal meatus suggests involvement of the posterior ethmoidal sinuses and/or sphenoidal sinus, so the answer is (B). None of the other options involve these sinuses.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The nasal polyp obstructing the superior nasal meatus suggests involvement of the posterior ethmoidal sinus, and the clear nasal discharge suggests chronic inflammation. Therefore, a CT scan of the head is most likely to show opacification of the sphenoidal sinus and posterior ethmoidal sinuses. Option A involves the pterygopalatine fossa, which is not typically obstructed in cases of nasal polyps. Option C involves the nasolacrimal duct and eustachian tube, which are not typically involved in cases of nasal polyps. Option D involves the frontal sinus and anterior ethmoidal sinus, which are not typically obstructed in cases of nasal polyps.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The superior nasal meatus drains into the posterior ethmoidal sinus, so if there is a nasal polyp obstructing it, it is most likely to cause opacification of the posterior ethmoidal sinuses and sphenoidal sinus on a CT scan of the head. All the other options do not drain into the superior nasal meatus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The nasal polyp obstructing the superior nasal meatus is most likely to cause opacification of the sphenoidal sinus and posterior ethmoidal sinuses, as these structures drain into the superior nasal meatus. All other options drain into different areas of the nasal cavity.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. A nasal polyp obstructing the superior nasal meatus is most likely to cause opacification of the sphenoidal sinus and posterior ethmoidal sinuses, as these are the closest structures to the site of obstruction. Options A, C, and D are not directly related to the site of obstruction.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The nasal polyp obstructing the superior nasal meatus suggests opacification of the sphenoidal sinus and posterior ethmoidal sinuses. All other options do not involve the superior nasal meatus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Nasal polyps often arise from the mucous membrane near the middle meatus and grow inward. The location of the obstruction in the superior nasal meatus places it near the posterior ethmoidal sinuses. Therefore, a CT scan of the head is most likely to show opacification of the sphenoidal sinus and posterior ethmoidal sinuses.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The nasal polyp obstructing the superior nasal meatus suggests inflammation of the ethmoid sinuses, which drains into the middle nasal meatus. Therefore, opacification of the posterior ethmoidal sinuses and sphenoidal sinus are the most likely findings on a CT scan.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The location of the nasal polyp is in the superior nasal meatus, which corresponds to the posterior ethmoidal sinus. Therefore, a CT scan of the head is most likely to show opacification of the sphenoidal sinus and posterior ethmoidal sinuses. Option A and D are incorrect because the polyp is not located in the middle or anterior ethmoid sinuses or the frontal sinus. Option C is incorrect because the nasolacrimal duct and eustachian tube are not related to the symptoms described.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The obstruction is located in the superior nasal meatus, which drains into the posterior ethmoidal sinuses. Therefore, the CT scan is most likely to show opacification of the sphenoidal sinus and posterior ethmoidal sinuses. The other options are not directly related to the location of the obstruction.
